company.name: W3 Innovations, LLC
company.business_description: W3 Innovations, LLC develops, markets, distributes, and sells software applications for mobile devices (apps) to consumers throughout the United States and provides online services to users of its apps. The company also operates under the business name Broken Thumbs Apps.

case_info.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c) and 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

complaint.factual_background: W3 Innovations, LLC (doing business as Broken Thumbs Apps) and its president Justin Maples developed and operated mobile apps directed to children under 13, including the Emily's Girl World app and several Emily Dress-up apps, which collected personal information—primarily email addresses—from child users. Over 30,000 email addresses were collected from users of these apps, along with personal information from hundreds of registered blog commenters. Despite operating online services clearly directed to children, Defendants never posted a privacy notice, never provided direct notice to parents, and never obtained verifiable parental consent before collecting children's personal information, in violation of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule (COPPA Rule). The apps were listed in the 'Games Kids' section of Apple's App Store, featured content aimed at elementary school-age girls, and actively solicited user submissions via email and blog comment forms.

representations_made.description: Defendants failed to maintain or link to an online notice of their information collection, use, and disclosure practices for the children's apps
representations_made.quoted_text: 9 23. Defendants have failed to maintain or link to an online notice of Defendants' 10 'nformation collection, use, and disclosure practices for the Emily's Girl World app and the 11 mily Dress-up apps.

representations_made.description: Defendants failed to provide direct notice to parents of their practices regarding collection, use, and/or disclosure of children's personal information
representations_made.quoted_text: 12 24. Defendants have not provided direct notice to parents of their practices regarding 13 he collection, use, and/or disclosure of children's personal information and other disclosures 14 equired by the Rule.

representations_made.description: Defendants failed to obtain verifiable consent from parents prior to collecting, using, or disclosing children's personal information
representations_made.quoted_text: 15 25. Defendants have not obtained verifiable consent from parents prior to collecting, 16 sing, or disclosing children's personal information.

counts.title: Violations of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule
counts.representation: Defendants operated online services directed to children (Emily's Girl World app and Emily Dress-up apps) and collected, maintained, and/or disclosed personal information from children under age 13 without: (a) posting a required privacy notice on their online services; (b) providing direct notice to parents of their information practices; or (c) obtaining verifiable parental consent before collecting children's personal information.
counts.fact: The COPPA Rule (16 C.F.R. Part 312) requires operators of online services directed to children to post a clear privacy notice (§ 312.4(b)), provide direct notice to parents (§ 312.4(c)), and obtain verifiable parental consent before collecting personal information from children (§ 312.5(a)(1)). Defendants collected over 30,000 email addresses and personal information from hundreds of child users without satisfying any of these requirements.
counts.conclusion: Therefore, Defendants have violated the Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 312, and Section 5(a)(1) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)(1).

definitions.Rule: the Federal Trade Commission's Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 312.
definitions.child, collects, collection, Commission,: mean as those terms are defined in Section 312.2 of the Rule, 16 C.F.R. § 312.2.
definitions.Corporate Defendant: W3 Innovations, LLC, and its successors and assigns.
definitions.Defendants: the Individual Defendant and the Corporate Defendant, individually, collectively, or in any combination.

provisions.title: Injunction — COPPA Compliance
provisions.summary: Defendants are permanently enjoined from violating COPPA by failing to provide required notices, failing to obtain verifiable parental consent, and otherwise violating the COPPA Rule.

requirements.description: Must not fail to provide sufficient notice of information collection practices on websites or online services directed to children, as required by Section 312.4(b) of the Rule
requirements.quoted_text: 20 A. Failing to provide sufficient notice of what information Defendants collect online 21 from children, how they use such information, their disclosure practices, and all 22 other content, on any website or online service that is directed to children, or any 23 website or online service through which they, with actual knowledge, collect, use, 24 andlor disclose personal information from children, as required by Section 25 312.4(b) of the Rule, 16 C.F.R. § 312.4(b);

requirements.description: Must not fail to provide direct notice to parents of information collection practices on websites or online services directed to children, as required by Section 312.4(c) of the Rule
requirements.quoted_text: 26 B. Failing to provide direct notice to parents of what information Defendants collect 27 online from children, how they use such information, their disclosure practices, 28 and all other required content, in connection with any website or online service onsent Decree and Order Page 3 of 15 Case5:11-cv-03958-PSG Document7 Filed09/08/11 Page4 of 15 1 that is directed to children, or any website or online service through which they, 2 with actual knowledge, collect, use, andlor disclose personal information from 3 children, as required by Section 312.4(c) ofthe Rule, 16 C.F.R. § 312.4(c);

requirements.description: Must not fail to obtain verifiable parental consent before any collection, use, and/or disclosure of personal information from children, as required by Section 312.5 of the Rule
requirements.quoted_text: 4 C. Failing to obtain verifiable parental consent before any collection, use, andlor 5 disclosure of personal information from children, in connection with any website 6 or online service that is directed to children, or on any website or online service 7 through which they, with actual knowledge, collect, use, and/or disclose personal 8 information from children, as required by Section 312.5 of the Rule, 16 C.F.R. § 9 312.5(a)(1); or,

requirements.description: Must not violate any other provision of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 312, as the Rule may hereafter be amended
requirements.quoted_text: 10 D. Violating any other provision of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule, 11 16 C.F .R. Part 312, and as the Rule may hereafter be amended. A copy of the 12 Rule is attached hereto as "Appendix A" and incorporated herein as if fully set 13 forth verbatim.

provisions.title: Deletion of Children's Personal Information
provisions.summary: Defendants must delete all personal information collected in violation of the Rule from April 21, 2000 through the date of the Order, within five days of entry.

requirements.description: Within five (5) days of entry of this Order, delete all personal information collected and maintained in violation of the Rule from April 21, 2000 through the date of entry of this Order
requirements.quoted_text: 15 16. IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that Defendants, within five (5) days from the date of 16 entry of this Order, shall delete all personal information collected and maintained in 17 violation of the Rule at any time from April 21, 2000 through the date of entry of this 18 ·Order.

provisions.title: Civil Penalty — Payment of $50,000
provisions.summary: Defendants must jointly and severally pay a civil penalty of $50,000 to the United States pursuant to Section 5(m)(1)(A) of the FTC Act.

requirements.description: Defendants, jointly and severally, shall pay to Plaintiff a civil penalty of $50,000 pursuant to Section 5(m)(1)(A) of the FTC Act
requirements.quoted_text: 20 17. IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that Defendants, jointly and severally, shall pay to 21 Plaintiff a civil penalty, pursuant to Section 5(m)(1)(A) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. 22 § 4S(m)(I)(A), in the amount of fifty thousand dollars ($50,000).

requirements.description: Prior to or concurrently with execution of this Order, Defendants shall turn over the full $50,000 civil penalty to their attorneys; within five (5) days of receipt of notice of entry of this Order, attorneys shall transfer the sum via wire transfer or certified cashier's check payable to the Treasurer of the United States
requirements.quoted_text: 23 18. Prior to or concurrently with Defendants' execution ofthis Order, Defendants shall turn 24 over the full amount of the civil penalty to their attorneys, who shall hold the entire sum 25 for no purpose other than payment to the Treasurer oftM United States after entry ofthis 26 Order by the Court. Within five (5) days of receipt of notice oftlie entry of this Order, 27 Defendants' attorneys shall transfer the sum of $50,000 in the form of a wire transfer or . 28 certified cashier's check made payable tothe Treasurer of the United States. The check . onsent Decree and Order Page 4 of 15 Case5:11-cv-03958-PSG Document7 Filed09/08/11 Page5 of 15 1 and/or written confirmation of the wire transfer shall be delivered in accordance with 2 procedures specified by the Office of Consumer Litigation, Civil Division, U.S. 3 Department of Justice, Washington, DC 20530.

requirements.description: Defendants relinquish all dominion, control, and title to the funds paid and shall make no claim to or demand return of the funds
requirements.quoted_text: 4 19. Defendants relinquish all dominion, control, and title to the funds paid to the fullest 5 extent permitted by law. Defendants shall make no claim to or demand return of the 6 funds, directly or indirectly, through counselor otherwise.

requirements.description: Defendants agree that facts alleged in the Complaint shall be taken as true in any subsequent civil litigation to enforce payment obligations under this Order
requirements.quoted_text: 7 O. Defendants agree that the facts as alleged in the Complaint filed in this action shall be 8 taken as true, without further proof, in any subsequent civil litigation filed by or on 9 behalf of the Commission solely to enforce its rights to any payment or money judgment 10 pursuant to this Order.

requirements.description: Defendants agree the judgment is a civil penalty owed to the U.S. Government, not compensation for pecuniary loss, and is not subject to discharge in bankruptcy under 11 U.S.C. § 523(a)(7)
requirements.quoted_text: 11 1. Defendants agree that the judgment represents a civil penalty owed to the United States 12 Government, is not compensation for actual pecuniary loss, and, therefore, as to the 13 Individual Defendant, is not subject to discharge under the Bankruptcy Code pursuant to 14 11 U.S.C. § 523(a)(7).

requirements.description: In the event of default in payment continuing for ten (10) days beyond the due date, the entire unpaid penalty plus interest shall immediately become due and payable
requirements.quoted_text: 15 2. In the event of any default in payment, which default continues for ten (10) days beyond 16 the due date of payment, the entire unpaid penalty, together with interest, as computed 17 pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 1961 (accrued from the date of default to the date of payment) 18 shall immediately become due and payable.

provisions.title: Compliance Monitoring
provisions.summary: The Commission is authorized to monitor compliance with the Order, including requiring written reports, document production, depositions, and business entry from Defendants within ten days of written notice.

requirements.description: Within ten (10) days of receipt of written notice from a Commission representative, Defendants shall submit sworn written reports, produce documents for inspection and copying, appear for deposition, and provide entry during normal business hours to any business location
requirements.quoted_text: 22 A. Within ten (10) days of receipt of written notice from a representative of the 23 Commission, Defendants each shall submit written reports, which are true and 24 accurate and sworn to under penalty of perjury; produce documents for inspection 25 and copying; appear for deposition; and provide entry during normal business 26 hours to any business location in each Defendant's possession or direct or indirect 27 control to inspect the business operation. Provided that Defendants, after 28 attempting to resolve any dispute without court action and for good cause shown, onsent Decree and Order Page 5 of15 Case5:11-cv-03958-PSG Document7 Filed09/08/11 Page6 of 15 1 may file a motion with this Court seeking an order including one or more of the 2 protections set forth in Fed. R. Civ. P. 26(c).

requirements.description: The Commission is authorized to use all other lawful means, including obtaining discovery from any person without further leave of court and having representatives pose as consumers and suppliers to Defendants
requirements.quoted_text: 3 B. In addition, the Commission is authorized to use all other lawful means, including 4 but not limited to: 5 1. Obtaining discovery from any person, without further leave of court, using 6 the procedures prescribed by Fed. R. Civ. P. 30, 31, 33, 34, 36, 45 and 69; 7 2. Having its representatives pose as consumers and suppliers to Defendants, 8 their employees, or any other entity managed or controlled in whole or in 9 part by any Defendant, without the necessity of identification or prior 10 notice; and,

requirements.description: Defendants shall permit Commission representatives to interview any employer, consultant, independent contractor, representative, agent, or employee who has agreed to such an interview relating to conduct subject to this Order
requirements.quoted_text: 11 C. Defendants each shall permit representatives of the Commission to interview any 12 employer, consultant, independent contractor, representative, agent, or employee 13 who has agreed to such an interview, relating in any way to any conduct subject 14 to this Order. The person interviewed may have counsel present, including 15 Defendants' counsel and any individual counsel.

requirements.description: For compliance reporting and monitoring purposes, the Commission is authorized to communicate directly with each Defendant
requirements.quoted_text: 16 D. For purposes of the compliance reporting and monitoring required by this Order, 17 the Commission is authorized to communicate directly with each Defendant.

provisions.title: Compliance Reporting
provisions.summary: Defendants must notify the Commission of personal and business changes for three years, file sworn written compliance reports beginning 60 days after entry, and notify the Commission of any bankruptcy filings within 15 days.

requirements.description: For three (3) years from entry, Individual Defendant shall notify the Commission within ten (10) days of any changes in residence/mailing address/telephone number
requirements.quoted_text: 26 A. For a period of three (3) years from the date of entry of this Order, 27 1. Individual Defendant shall notifY the Commission of the following: 28 a. Any changes in such Defendant's residence, mailing address. and onsent Decree and Order Page 6 of 15 Case5:11-cv-03958-PSG Document7 Filed09/08/11 Page7 of 15 1 telephone number, within ten (10) days of the date of such change;

requirements.description: For three (3) years from entry, Individual Defendant shall notify the Commission within ten (10) days of changes in employment status, self-employment, or ownership interest in any business entity, including details of such business
requirements.quoted_text: 2 b. Any changes in such Defendant's employment status (including 3 self-employment), and any change in such Defendant's ownership 4 in any business entity, within ten (10) days of the date of such 5 change. Such notice shall include the name and address of each 6 business that such Defendant is affiliated with, employed by, 7 creates or forms, or performs services for; a detailed description of 8 the nature of the business; and a detailed description of such 9 Defendant's duties and responsibilities in connection with the 10 business or employment; and,

requirements.description: For three (3) years from entry, Individual Defendant shall notify the Commission within ten (10) days of any changes in name or use of aliases or fictitious names
requirements.quoted_text: 11 c. Any changes in such Defendant's name or use of any aliases or 12 fictitious names within ten (10) days of the date of such change;

requirements.description: Defendants shall notify the Commission of changes in structure of the Corporate Defendant or any controlled business entity at least thirty (30) days prior to such change, or as soon as practicable if learned less than thirty days in advance
requirements.quoted_text: 13 2. Defendants shall notifY the Commission of any changes in structure of the 14 Corporate Defendant or any business entity that any Defendant directly or 15 indirectly controls, or has an ownership interest in, that may affect 16 compliance obligations arising under this Order, including but not limited 17 to: incorporation or other organization; a dissolution, assignment, sale, 18 merger, or other action; the creation or dissolution of a subsidiary, parent, 19 or affiliate that engages in any acts or practices subject to this Order; or a 20 change in the business name or address, at least thirty (30) days prior to 21 such ch!IDge, prOVided that, with respect to any such change in the 22 business entity about which a Defendant learns less than thirty (30) days 23 prior to the date such action is to take place, such Defendant shall notify 24 the Commission as soon as is practicable after obtaining such knowledge.

requirements.description: Sixty (60) days after entry of the Order, and thereafter for three (3) years as the FTC requires, each Defendant shall provide a sworn written report to the Commission detailing compliance, including personal/business information for the Individual Defendant and detailed information about websites, privacy notices, parental consent methods, and data protection procedures for the Corporate Defendant
requirements.quoted_text: 25 B. Sixty (60) days after the date of entry of this Order, and thereafter for a period of 26 three (3) years, at such times as the Federal Trade Commission shall reasonably 27 require, Defendants each shall provide a written report to the Commission, which 28 is true and accurate and sworn to under penalty of perjury, setting forth in detail onsent Decree and Order Page 7 of 15 Case5:11-cv-03958-PSG Document7 Filed09/08/11 Page8 of 15 1 the manner and form in which each has complied and is complying with this 2 Order. Any other changes required to be reported under Subsection A of 14 this Section. 15 2. For the Corporate Defendant and Individual Defendant, for any business 16 which they, individually or collectively, own a majority interest in or 17 directly or indirectly control: 18 a. A statement setting forth in detail the criteria and process through 19 which any of Defendant's websites or online services enable the 20 collection or disclosure of personal information, and a copy of 21 each different version of screen or page where personal 22 information can be collected or disclosed; 23 b. requirements.description: Each Defendant shall notify the Commission of the filing of a bankruptcy petition within fifteen (15) days of filing
requirements.quoted_text: 20 c. Each Defendant shall notify the Commission of the filing of a bankruptcy petition 21 by such Defendant within fifteen (15) days of filing.

requirements.description: Defendants shall send all required reports and notifications by overnight courier (or first-class mail with simultaneous email to DEBrief@ftc.gov) to the Associate Director for Enforcement, Bureau of Consumer Protection, Federal Trade Commission

RE: v. W3 Innovations. LLC 4 5 Provided that, in lieu of overnight courier, Defendants may send such reports or 6 notifications by first-class mail, but only if Defendants contemporaneously send 7 an electronic version of such report or notification to the Commission at: 8 DEBrief@ftc.gov.

provisions.title: Recordkeeping Provisions
provisions.summary: For six years from entry of the Order, Defendants must create and retain records sufficient to demonstrate full compliance, including acknowledgments, compliance reports, and copies of all forms and pages through which children's personal information is collected or disclosed.

requirements.description: For six (6) years from entry of the Order, Defendants must create and retain copies of all documents necessary to demonstrate full compliance, including acknowledgments of receipt of the Order, all reports submitted to the Commission, and sample copies of every materially different form or web page through which personal information is collected or disclosed from children
requirements.quoted_text: 5. IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that, for a period of six (6) years from the date of entry of 11 this Order, Corporate Defendant and Individual Defendant, for any business engaged in 12 activities relating to the subject matter of this Order, and which they. individually or 13 collectively, own a majority interest in or directly or indirectly control, are hereby 14 restrained and enjoined from failing to create and retain the following records: 15 A. A print or electronic copy of all documents necessary to demonstrate full 16 compliance with each provision of this Order, including, but not limited to: 17 1. Copies of acknowledgments of receipt of this Order required by Sections 18 titled "Distribution of Order" and "Acknowledgment of Receipt of 19 Order"; 20 2. All reports submitted to the Commission pursuant to the Section titled 21 "Compliance Reporting"; 22 3. A sample copy of every materially different fonn, page, or screen through 23 which personal infonnation is collected or disclosed, and a sample copy of 24 each materially different document containing any representation 25 regarding Defendants' collection, use, and disclosure practices pertaining 26 to personal infonnation of a child. Each web page copy shall be 27 accompanied by the URL of the web page where the material was posted 28 onsent Decree and Order Page ,10 of 15 Case5:11-cv-03958-PSG Document7 Filed09/08/11 Page11 of 15 1 online. Electronic copies shall include all text and graphics files, audio 2 scripts, and other computer files used in presenting information. 3 Provided, however, that Defendants shall not be required to retain any 4 document for longer than two (2) years after the document was created, or 5 to retain a print or electronic copy of any amended form, page, or screen 6 to the extent that the amendment does not affect Defendants' compliance 7 obligations under this Order.

provisions.title: Distribution of Order
provisions.summary: For three years, Defendants must deliver copies of the Order to relevant personnel and business entities and obtain signed acknowledgments of receipt within 30 days of delivery.

requirements.description: Corporate Defendant must deliver a copy of this Order to all principals, officers, directors, managers, and relevant employees/agents within five (5) days of service; to new personnel prior to their assuming responsibilities; and to any successor business entity at least ten (10) days prior to any structural change
requirements.quoted_text: 12 A. Corporate Defendant: The Corporate Defendant must deliver a copy of this Order 13 to: (1) all of its principals, officers, directors, and managers; (2) all of its 14 employees, agents, and representatives who have responsibilities related to the 15 operation of any website or online service subject to this Order; and (3) any 16 business entity resulting from any change in structure set forth in Subsection A.2. 17 ofthe Section titled "Compliance Reporting." For current personnel, delivery 18 shall be within five (5) days of service of this Order upon each such Defendant. 19 For new personnel, delivery shall occur prior to their assuming their 20 responsibilities. For any business elltity resulting from any change in structure set 21 forth in Subsection A.2. of the Section titled "Compliance Reporting,''> delivery 22 shall be at least ten (10) days prior to the change in structure.
requirements.deadline: 5 days of service (current personnel); 10 days prior (structural changes)

requirements.description: Individual Defendant, for any business they own or control related to the subject matter of the Order, must deliver a copy of this Order to all principals, officers, directors, managers, and relevant employees/agents within five (5) days of service; to new personnel prior to their assuming responsibilities; and to any successor business entity at least ten (10) days prior to any structural change
requirements.quoted_text: 23 B. Individual Defendant as control person: For any business engaged in activities 24 related to the subject matter of this Order, and that the Individual Defendant owns 25 a majority interest in or directly or indirectly controls, Individual Defendant must 26 deliver a copy of this Order to: (1) all principals, officers, directors, and managers 27 of that business; (2) all employees, agents, and representatives of that business 28 who engage in activities related to the subject matter of the Order; and (3) any onsent Decree and Order Page 11 of15 Case5:11-cv-03958-PSG Document7 Filed09/08/11 Page12 of 15 1 business entity resulting from any change in structure set forth in Subsection A.2. 2 of the Section titled "Compliance Reporting." For current personnel, delivery 3 shall be within five (5) days of service of this Order upon such Defendant. For 4 new personnel, delivery shall occur prior to their assuming their responsibilities. 5 For any business entity resulting from any change in structure set forth in 6 Subsection A.2. of the Section titled "Compliance Reporting," delivery shall be at 7 least ten (10) days prior to the change in structure.
requirements.deadline: 5 days of service (current personnel); 10 days prior (structural changes)

requirements.description: Defendants must secure a signed and dated acknowledgment of receipt of the Order within thirty (30) days of delivery from all persons receiving a copy, and maintain copies of signed statements and related information, making them available to the Commission upon request
requirements.quoted_text: 8 C. Defendants must secure a signed and dated statement acknowledging receipt of 9 the Order, within thirty (30) days of delivery, from all persons receiving a copy of 10 the Order pursuant to this Se.ction. Defendants shall maintain copies of the signed 11 statements, as well as other information regarding the fact and manner of its 12 compliance, including the name and title of each person to whom a copy of the 13 Order has been provided and, upon request, shall make the statements and other 14 information available to the Commission.

provisions.title: Acknowledgment of Receipt of Order
provisions.summary: Each Defendant must submit a sworn statement to the Commission acknowledging receipt of the Order within five business days of its entry by the Court.

requirements.description: Each Defendant, within five (5) business days of receipt of this Order as entered by the Court, must submit to the Commission a truthful sworn statement acknowledging receipt of this Order
requirements.quoted_text: 16 7. IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that each Defendant, within five (5) business days of 17 receipt of this Order as entered by the Court, must submit to the Commission a truthful 18 sworn statement acknowledging receipt of this Order.

provisions.title: Provision of Taxpayer Identifying Numbers
provisions.summary: Corporate Defendant must furnish its taxpayer identifying number (employer identification number) to the FTC for purposes of collecting and reporting any delinquent amounts.

requirements.description: Corporate Defendant is required, in accordance with 31 U.S.C. § 7701, to furnish to the Federal Trade Commission its taxpayer identifying number (employer identification number) for purposes of collecting and reporting any delinquent amount arising out of its relationship with the government
requirements.quoted_text: 20 8. IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that the Corporate Defendant is hereby required, in 21 accordance with 31 U.S.C. § 7701, to furnish to the Federal Trade Commission its 22 taxpayer identifying number (employer identification number), which shall be used for 23 purposes of collecting and reporting any delinquent amount arising out of its relationship 24 with the government.

provisions.title: Retention of Jurisdiction
provisions.summary: The Court retains jurisdiction over this matter for the purposes of construction, modification, and enforcement of the Order.

requirements.description: This Court shall retain jurisdiction of this matter for the purposes of construction, modification, and enforcement of this Order
requirements.quoted_text: 26 9. This Court shall retain jurisdiction of this matter for the purposes of construction, 27 modification, and enforcement of this Order.

duration.termination_text: This Court shall retain jurisdiction of this matter for the purposes of construction, modification, and enforcement of this Order.
